Comment:
You can analyze the game here:
http://gameknot.com/anbd.pl?bd=8140443&fb=1&rnd=0.47384035058167306

We played Danish gambit opening as a theme in a mini-tournament. This is the last forced move. 

White sacrifices two pawns for a strong attack on the king-side. 
Blacks biggest disadvantage is he is behind in development.

We played Danish gambit opening as a theme in a mini-tournament. This is the last forced move. 

White sacrifices two pawns for a strong attack on the king-side. 
Blacks biggest disadvantage is he is behind in development.
Black sacrifices the queen-pawn, the Schlechter defense.

All book moves until now:
* Material is even.
* Whites doubled bishops are gone but still has a strong dark bishop on the long diagonal. It is aiming straight at blacks king. 
* White has moved his light bishop three times, but black is still behind in development
* Blacks king is weakened.
* Both white and black has a passed pawn.
* White have lots of open files for his rooks.

Challenging whites domination on the dark squares and develops - blacks greatest weakness.
Developing with tempo - white must defend his e4 pawn.
Developing with tempo - white must defend his e4 pawn.
A more active position than d7.
A more active position than d7.
Finally black is fully developed.
Finally black is fully developed.

Challenging the d-file. 
However it allows me to do Nb4. An important part of chess anticipate your opponents moves and suppress his counter-play.

Preparing a queen side pawn storm and threatens to swipe the "evil" black bishop off the board with Nd3 . 
Why I don't like the bishop:
* It is aiming for my king.
* White can also trade on f6 whenever he wants, making my calculations more complicated.

Defends c3.
To my opinion a too defensive move - white is giving up territory.
Kicking my knight.
Kicking my knight.

Better is to fall back 16 .. Nc6, especially since I played c5 before.
But I wanted more action :-)
Avoiding 18 Bxf6 19 Rxb7 or 17 .. Nd4 18 Bxd4 cxd4 19 Rxb7 and improves the pawns.
Avoiding 18 Bxf6 19 Rxb7 or 17 .. Nd4 18 Bxd4 cxd4 19 Rxb7 and improves the pawns.
Threatens the knight d4 retreat.

19 Bxd4! - White sacrifices his evil dark bishop, a wakeup call for me!

Now I will loose a pawn. I just have to decide the best way to do it. My plan is to improve the light bishop and disrupt his position.

19 Bxd4! - White sacrifices his evil dark bishop, a wakeup call for me!

Now I will loose a pawn. I just have to decide the best way to do it. My plan is to improve the light bishop and disrupt his position.
Here it comes - a triple attack
Here it comes - a triple attack
Hard to hit a moving target.
An aggressive bishop position.
An aggressive bishop position.
A Knight on the rim is dim - but necessary to catch the pawn.
